subject: Re: [junit] Junit Newbie
msgSnippet: Andrew - The ambition is really to replace System.out.println() statements used during development for debugging purposes (e.g. got here , got there , etc.)
messageBody:
Andrew -

The ambition is really to replace System.out.println() statements
used during development for debugging purposes (e.g. "got here", "got
there", etc.) with test cases that don't require this sort of visual
inspection and will stand the test of time. Error, warning, and debug
statements used to communicate to the user of production software
should not in general be replaced.

In the example below, I'd first change the loadDriver method to throw
the ClassNotFoundException. Then I'd write a test method that
exercises the loadDriver() method and verify that the test fails when
the ClassNotFoundException is thrown.

Mike

--- Andrew Wilkie <andrew.wilkie@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Group,
>
> Just started to use JUnit on my first Java project at work. Got it
> setup and outputting into message view of JBuilder.
>
> All the articles I read say to replace any System.out.println() calls
> with test cases. I am unable to get this to work when
> the System.out.println() is contained within the Catch statement of a
> Try/Catch block.
>
> In the code below, this is the line "System.out.println("Unable to
> load Driver Class");"
>
> ===================================================
> package testjdbc;
>
> import java.sql.*;
>
> public class JDBCSample
> {
> public JDBCSample()
> {
> }
>
> public boolean loadDriver()
> {
> try
> {
> // This is where we load the driver by calling in a class
> through its
> // string name using the forName method.
> Class.forName("oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver");
> }
> catch (ClassNotFoundException e)
> {
> System.out.println("Unable to load Driver Class");
> }
> }
> }
> ===================================================
>
> I'm sure there is a simple explanation to this, but I am unable to
> work it out.
>
> Any help is greatlly appreciated.
>
> Cheers,
> Andrew
>
